Sentences: Good afternoon.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: At the Federal Reserve, we are strongly committed to achieving the monetary policy goals that Congress has given us—maximum employment and price stability.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Since the beginning of the pandemic, we have taken forceful actions to provide relief and stability, to ensure that the recovery will be as strong as possible, and to limit lasting damage to the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Today my colleagues on the FOMC and I reaffirmed our strong forward guidance for interest rates and also provided additional guidance for our asset purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Together, these measures will ensure that monetary policy will continue to deliver powerful support to the economy until the recovery is complete.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Economic activity has continued to recover from its depressed second-quarter level.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The substantial reopening of the economy led to a rapid rebound in activity, and real GDP rose at an annual rate of 33 percent in the third quarter.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In recent months, however, the pace of improvement has moderated.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Household spending on goods, especially durable goods, has been strong and has moved above its pre-pandemic level.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In contrast, spending on services remains low, especially in sectors that typically require people to gather closely, including travel and hospitality.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The overall rebound in household spending owes in part to federal stimulus payments and expanded unemployment benefits, which provided essential support to many families and individuals.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The housing sector has fully recovered from the downturn, supported in part by low mortgage interest rates.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Business investment has also picked up.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The recovery has progressed more quickly than generally expected, and forecasts from FOMC participants for economic growth this year have been revised up since our September Summary of Economic Projections.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Even so, overall economic activity remains well below its level before the pandemic, and the path ahead remains highly uncertain.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In the labor market, more than half of the 22 million jobs that were lost in March and April have been regained, as many people were able to return to work.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As with overall economic activity, the pace of improvement in the labor market has moderated.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Job growth slowed to 245,000 in November, and while the unemployment rate has continued to decline, it remains elevated at 6.7 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Participation in the labor market remains notably below pre-pandemic levels.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Although there has been much progress in the labor market since the spring, we will not lose sight of the millions of Americans who remain out of work.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Looking ahead, FOMC participants project the unemployment rate to continue to decline; the median projection is 5 percent at the end of next year and moves below 4 percent by 2023.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The economic downturn has not fallen equally on all Americans, and those least able to shoulder the burden have been the hardest hit.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In particular, the high level of joblessness has been especially severe for lower-wage workers in the service sector and for African Americans and Hispanics.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The economic dislocation has upended many lives and created great uncertainty about the future.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The pandemic has also left a significant imprint on inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Following large declines in the spring, consumer prices picked up over the summer but have leveled out more recently.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: For those sectors that have been most adversely affected by the pandemic, prices remain particularly soft.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Overall, on a 12-month basis, inflation remains below our 2 percent longer-run objective.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The median inflation projection from FOMC participants rises from 1.2 percent this year to 1.8 percent next year and reaches 2 percent in 2023.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As we have emphasized throughout the pandemic, the outlook for the economy is extraordinarily uncertain and will depend in large part on the course of the virus.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Recent news on vaccines has been very positive.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: However, significant challenges and uncertainties remain with regard to the timing, production, and distribution of vaccines as well as their efficacy across different groups.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It remains difficult to assess the timing and scope of the economic implications of these developments.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The ongoing surge in new COVID-19 cases, both here in the United States and abroad, is particularly concerning, and the next few months are likely to be very challenging.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: All of us have a role to play in our nation’s response to the pandemic.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Following the advice of public health professionals to keep appropriate social distances and to wear masks in public will help get the economy back to full strength.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: A full economic recovery is unlikely until people are confident that it is safe to engage—reengage in a broad range of activities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As we previously announced, we are now releasing the entire package of our SEP materials at the same time as our FOMC statement.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Included in these materials are two new exhibits that show how the balance of participants’ assessments of uncertainty and risks have evolved over time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Since the onset of the pandemic, nearly all participants continue to judge the level of uncertainty about the economic outlook as elevated.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In terms of risks to the outlook, fewer participants see the balance of risks as weighted to the downside than in September.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: While a little more than half of participants now judge risks to be broadly balanced for economic activity, a similar number continue to see risks weighted to the downside for inflation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The Fed’s response to this crisis has been guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people, along with our responsibilities to promote the stability of the financial system.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As noted in our Statement on Longer-Run Goals and Monetary Policy Strategy, we view maximum employment as a broad-based and inclusive goal.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Our ability to achieve maximum employment in the years ahead depends importantly on having longer-term inflation expectations well anchored at 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As we reiterated in today’s statement, with inflation running persistently below 2 percent, we will aim to achieve inflation moderately above 2 percent for some time so that inflation averages 2 percent over time and longer-term inflation expectations remain well anchored at 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We expect to maintain an accommodative stance of monetary policy until these employment and inflation outcomes are achieved.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: With regard to interest rates, we continue to expect it will be appropriate to maintain the current 0 to ¼ percent target range for the federal funds rate until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee’s assessment of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In addition, as we noted in today’s policy statement, we will continue to increase our holdings of Treasury securities by at least $80 billion per month and of agency mortgage-backed securities by at least $40 billion per month until substantial further progress has been made toward our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We believe the increase in our balance sheet this year has materially eased financial conditions and is providing substantial support to the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Combined with our forward guidance for the federal funds rate, our enhanced balance sheet guidance will ensure that the stance of monetary policy remains highly accommodative as the recovery progresses.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Our guidance is outcome based and is tied to progress toward reaching our employment and inflation goals.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thus, if progress toward our goals were to slow, the guidance would convey our intention to increase policy accommodation through a lower expected path of the federal funds rate and a higher expected path of the balance sheet.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Overall, our interest rate and balance sheet tools are providing powerful support to the economy and will continue to do so.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The Federal Reserve has also been taking broad and forceful actions to more directly support the flow of credit in the economy for households, for businesses large and small, and for state and local governments.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Preserving the flow of credit is essential for mitigating damage to the economy and promoting a robust recovery.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Many of our programs rely on emergency lending powers that require the support of the Treasury Department and are available only in very unusual circumstances, such as those we find ourselves in today.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: These programs serve as a backstop to key credit markets and have helped to restore the flow of credit from private lenders through normal channels.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We have deployed these lending powers to an unprecedented extent, enabled in large part by financial backing and support from Congress and the Treasury.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Although funds from the CARES Act will not be available to support new loans or new purchases after—of assets after December 31, the Treasury could authorize support for emerging lending facilities, if needed, through the Exchange Stabilization Fund.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: When the time comes, after the crisis has passed, we will put these emergency tools back in the box.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As I have emphasized before, these are lending powers, not spending powers.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The Fed cannot grant money to particular beneficiaries.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We can only create programs or facilities with broad-based eligibility to make loans to solvent entities with the expectation that the loans will be repaid.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Many borrowers are benefiting from these programs, as is the overall economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But for many others, getting a loan that may be difficult to repay may not be the answer.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In these cases, direct fiscal support may be needed.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Elected officials have the power to tax and spend and to make decisions about where we, as a society, should direct our collective resources.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The fiscal policy actions that have been taken thus far have made a critical difference to families, businesses, and communities across the country.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Even so, the current economic downturn is the most severe of our lifetimes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It will take a while to get back to the levels of economic activity and employment that prevailed at the beginning of this year, and it may take continued support from both monetary and fiscal policy to achieve that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Everything we do is in service to our public mission.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We are committed to using our full range of tools to support the economy and to help assure that the recovery from this difficult period will be as robust as possible.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I look forward to your questions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Rich Miller.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you very much, Mr. Chairman.
Speaker: RICH MILLER.

Sentences: Thank you, Michelle.
Speaker: RICH MILLER.

Sentences: I wonder if I could start with the, the SEP.  We have—unemployment now is at 6.7, the SEP median sees, sees it falling to 5.
Speaker: RICH MILLER.

Sentences: Headline inflation is one time 1.2, the SEP median sees it rising to 1.8.
Speaker: RICH MILLER.

Sentences: And core inflation is 1.4, and the SEP sees it rising to 1.8 likewise.
Speaker: RICH MILLER.

Sentences: Would that constitute “substantial further progress” toward the Committee’s maximum-employment and price-stability goals?
Speaker: RICH MILLER.

Sentences: Yes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Well, so we’re not—we’re not going to be identifying specific—associating that test with, with specific numbers at this point.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, really, the question is, what do we mean by, by that language?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, really, the overarching message, Rich, is that our guidance for both interest rates and asset purchases will keep monetary policy accommodative until our maximum-employment and price-stability goals are achieved, and that’s, that’s a powerful message.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So “substantial further progress” means what it says.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It means we’ll be looking for employment to be substantially closer to assessments of its maximum level and inflation to be substantially closer to our 2 percent longer-run goal before we start making adjustments to our purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I would also point out that by increasing our asset holdings, we see ourselves as adding policy accommodation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There will come a time when the economy does not require increasing amounts of policy accommodation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And when that time comes—and that will be uncertain and, in any case, is, is some ways off.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I can’t give you an exact set of numbers.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We will—of course, as we approach that point, we’ll be evaluating that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And when we see ourselves on a path to achieve that goal, then we will—we will say so undoubtedly well in advance of any time when we would actually consider gradually tapering the pace of purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Very quickly on, on that.
Speaker: RICH MILLER.

Sentences: You, you mentioned the next couple months are going to be very challenging.
Speaker: RICH MILLER.

Sentences: And regarding asset purchases, why not increase the duration of the asset purchases at this time, given what you see as a very challenging period ahead?
Speaker: RICH MILLER.

Sentences: So, you know, again, I would start with what we actually did at the meeting, which, which was, we provided this, this guidance about the path of asset purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I just went through what, what they—what they—the guidance that we put forward.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, so I guess since September we’ve now adopted a flexible average inflation-targeting framework.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We have provided rate guidance that is tightly linked to the goals as expressed in that new framework.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And now we’ve done the same for, for asset purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, you know, we’ve, we’ve been sort of—as, as the future has become clearer and as we’ve absorbed new developments in medical—in the medical sphere and also in, in the economy, we have—began to be able to see further.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we’ve, we’ve started to be able to provide further important guidance.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we think that the—that the asset purchase guidance, guidance is very important.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We think that the, the prior language of “in coming months” was obviously temporary.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: This links that guidance, those purchases, to actual “substantial further progress” toward our, our mandated goals.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We think that’s important.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we think that that is important to have done.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I, I would just add, though, that we also continue to think that our current policy stance is appropriate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We think it’s providing a great deal of support for the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Financial conditions are highly accommodative.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, we monitor a range of financial condition indexes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There are many of them, and they’ll, they’ll all pretty much tell you that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You can—you can also look at the interest sensitive parts of the economy—for example, housing, durable sales, vehicle sales—those parts of the economy are, are performing very, very well.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The parts of the economy that are weak are the service-sector businesses that involve close contact.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Those are not being held back by financial conditions, but rather by the spread of the virus.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I’ll close by, by just saying, we do have the flexibility to provide more accommodation through the channel you mentioned and through other channels.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we recognize that circumstances could shift in a way that warrants our, our doing that, including by adjusting purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We are committed to using our full range of tools to support the U.S. economy to achieve our goals.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We will continue to use our tools to support the economy for as long as it takes until the job is well and truly done.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: No one should doubt that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: RICH MILLER.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Nick Timiraos.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: Nick Timiraos, the Wall Street Journal.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: Chair Powell, a two-part question.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: What, if anything, would prompt the Fed to shift Treasury purchases toward the longer end of the curve as you did with your prior QE programs?
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: And does your guidance today on asset purchases foreclose the possibility that you could, at some point, lengthen maturities while simultaneously tapering the monthly purchase amounts?
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: Well, Nick, I—on, on the first part of the question, I, I don’t—I wouldn’t want to sort of talk about hypothetical situations.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, we, we look at our overall stance of policy, we look at overall financial conditions, we look at what’s going on in the economy—different parts of the economy, and we ask ourselves, should we change our policy stance?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We do that at every meeting.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we look at where financial conditions are now, and, and we, we feel that they are appropriate for now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Anytime we feel like the economy could, could use stronger accommodation, we would be prepared to provide it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We—but right now, we’re providing a great deal, and we think—we happen to think it’s the right amount.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, you, you mentioned—I think you’re referring to the idea of maintaining the duration but, but reducing the quantity, which is sort of what the Bank of Canada did.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that, that is something that we—you know, that we talked about in the last meeting and was addressed in the minutes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I would say, the views on that were mixed:  Some thought it was an interesting idea, others not so much.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I, I wouldn’t say that that’s something that’s, that’s high on our list of, of possibilities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Victoria.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, Victoria Guida with Politico.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentences: I wanted to ask about the 13(3) facilities.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentences: Chair Powell, you’ve said that you accept Treasury Secretary Mnuchin’s interpretation of the statute of the CARES Act on, on what should happen with those programs.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentences: So, first of all, I’m curious whether under a new Treasury Secretary you will accept whatever legal interpretation they put forward for those programs.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentences: And then, also, given that there isn’t a statutory requirement for you to have financial backing from Treasury for 13(3) facilities, do you have any plans for any future facilities that don’t require Treasury backing?
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentences: So on your—on your first question, we really have not thought about that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re, we’re very focused on—we have a lot to do now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We, we have not focused on, on that question, and I, I really have nothing to add on that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Your second question is—sorry.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Oh, if there were no—yes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: No, we, we would have the ability—certainly, we would have the ability to do facilities under 13(3) in some cases with no backing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But we can’t do any 13(3) facilities without the approval of the Treasury Secretary, right?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But we did some facilities—I think one of our facilities this time didn’t have any Treasury backing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I think some in the—in the round of—during the Global Financial Crisis also didn’t have any.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So do you have any plans—like, would you consider doing more facilities if that became necessary without Treasury backing?
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentences: I would say that we are—you know, we’re—we have the authorities we have.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We will use them if, if they’re needed and if—and if the law permits us to do so.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We would—we would always do that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We, we do not have any plans for, for the future about this.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We—we’re very focused on, on getting through year-end.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’ve been very focused on, on the issues that are right in front of us.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, honestly, we’re not—we’re not planning on anything or having any discussions about what we might do down the road.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: VICTORIA GUIDA.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Steve Liesman.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you, Mr. Chairman, and happy New Year.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: I know how much you enjoy talking about fiscal stimulus, so let me ask you directly about fiscal stimulus.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: There’s talk right now of a $900 billion fiscal stimulus program in Congress.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Is, is that sufficient?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Is that what you’re looking for?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Do you think that’ll be sufficient for helping the economy?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Finally, you talked about the idea of how concerning the recent surge is.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: I wonder if you can put some detail on that.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: How much concern do you have in terms of, where could employment go?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: What could happen to GDP in the first quarter as a result of this surge?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Okay.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So on, on fiscal policy, I would just say a couple of things.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The case for fiscal policy right now is, is very, very strong.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I think that is widely understood, I would say, now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The details of it are entirely up to Congress.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But with the expiration of unemployment benefits—some of the unemployment benefits, the expiration of eviction moratoriums with the virus spreading the way it is, there’s a need for households and businesses to have, have fiscal support.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I do think that—again, I think that is widely understood.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I think it would be—I, I certainly would welcome the work that Congress is doing right now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s not up to us to judge that work.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s really, really theirs.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I, I don’t have a view for you on, on the size of it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s—you know, it’s obviously a substantial bill.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: On the surge, you know, so it’s a really interesting question.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We have, and others too, have consistently expected there to be more economic—that, that cases would hold—growth in cases would hold back the economy more than it actually has.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we’ve overestimated the, the effects on the economy of, of these spikes we’ve been having.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Now, this spike is so much larger that I think—and I think forecasters generally do think that there—that this will have an effect on suppressing activity, particularly activity that involves people getting together in bars and restaurants, on airplanes and hotels and things like that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And you’re starting to see that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In the—in the high-frequency data, you’re now beginning to see that show up.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I think if this is—the case numbers are so high and so widespread across the country that that, that seems like it must happen.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Now, how big will it be?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We don’t—we don’t really know.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, there are—there are a lot of estimates.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The general expectation is, you’re seeing some slowing now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And you’ll see the first quarter could well be—what, what we said is that coming months are going to be challenging.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The first quarter will, will certainly show significant effects from this.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: At the same time, people are getting vaccinated now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They’re getting vaccinated.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And by the end of the first quarter into the second quarter, you’re going to be seeing significant numbers of people vaccinated.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And so then what will be—how will that play into economic activity?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Again, we don’t have any experience with this.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You have to think that sometime in the middle of next year, you will—you will see people feeling comfortable going out and engaging in a broader range of activities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And some people will be probably quick to do that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Some are doing it now without a vaccine—right?—in many parts of the country.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, nonetheless, my expectation—and I think many people have the expectation that the second half of next year should—the economy should be performing strongly.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We should be—you know, we should be getting people back to work.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Businesses should be reopening and that kind of thing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The issue is more the next four or five months—getting through the next four, five, six months.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That is key.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, and, you know, clearly there’s going to be need for help there.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, and, you know, my sense and hope is that we’ll be getting that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Jeanna Smialek.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, Chair Powell.
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: Thank you for taking our questions.
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: I was wondering if you could talk a little bit about house prices.
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: They were mentioned in the most recent minutes as, you know, potentially a valuation concern, especially as it related to your mortgage-backed security purchases.
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: And you mentioned earlier today that the housing market looks more or less fully healed.
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: And so I guess I wonder, are you worried about valuation pressures there?
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: And, if so, what can the Fed do to contain those?
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: You know, so we monitor basically just about every asset price in the economy, and housing prices are something that we’ve been monitoring.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And you see them moving up.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You see very high demand.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: This, this is the housing market that people have been expecting since, you know, 2010.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, and then, you know, not many, when the—when the pandemic hit, thought, “Oh, this is what—this is what will produce that housing market,” but it has.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Now, I would say, from a financial stability standpoint, housing prices are not—are not of a level of concern right now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s just reflective of a lot of demand.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, builders are going to bring forth supply.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There’s also a sense that this—some of this may be pent-up demand from when the economy was closed, which would imply that demand—once that demand is met, that the real level of demand will be more manageable.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So it’s a—it’s a healthy economy now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We, we met recently with a bunch of homebuilders, and many of them in the business 30, 40 years said they’ve never seen the likes of it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, no, housing prices themselves are not—are not a financial stability concern at the moment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We will watch that carefully.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But in the near term, I wouldn’t think that that’s an issue that we’d be concerned about.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thanks.
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Edward Lawrence.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you for the question, Mr. Chairman.
Speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE.

Sentences: So with the actions that you’ve currently taken, how do you—how do you further fight a slowdown that you’re seeing?
Speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE.

Sentences: We’ve talked about the retail sales numbers are a little bit sluggish this month, the unemployment, the job growth has slowed down.
Speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE.

Sentences: Is there more the Fed can do to fight this?
Speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE.

Sentences: Or is it now squarely in the Congress’s realm?
Speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE.

Sentences: There is more that we can do, certainly.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We can—we can expand our, our asset purchase programs.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We can focus them more on the longer end.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There are a number of options we would have to provide more support to the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I would—I would say, though, that in the near term, the help that people need isn’t just from low interest rates that stimulates demand over time and works with long and variable lags.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s really support.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As the—as—we’ve, we’ve talked about this as all of these government policies trying to work together to create a bridge across this chasm, economic chasm that was created by the pandemic.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And for many Americans, that bridge is there and, and they’re across it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But there’s a group for, for which they, they don’t have a bridge yet.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that’s who we’re talking about here.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s, it’s the 10 million people who lost their jobs.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s people who may lose their homes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s—you know, you see the, the—many, many millions of Americans are, are waiting in food lines in their cars these days all over the country.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we know there’s need out there.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We know there are small businesses all over the country that, that have been basically unable to really function, and they’re just hanging on.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So—and, and they’re, they’re so critical to our economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So—and, by the way, now that we can—we can kind of see the light at the end of the tunnel, it would be—it would be bad to see, you know, people losing their business, their life’s work in many cases, or even generations’ worth of work, because they couldn’t last another few months, which is what it amounts to.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we have more we can do.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we’ll—I, I think more the issue is, we’re going to need to continue to provide support to this economy for quite a period of time, because the, the economy will be growing in expectation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We should be growing at a fairly healthy clip by the second half of next year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But it’s going to be a while before we really are back to the levels of, of labor market—the, the sort of conditions in the labor market that we had in early this year and for much of the last couple of years.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s how I think about it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Howard Schneider.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, Chair Powell.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: Thanks for doing this.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: And thanks, Michelle.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: Two, two quick questions.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: One, on the vaccine, do you have, or has the Fed modeled, sort of a working estimate of when the U.S. might reach something approaching herd immunity?
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: And, secondly, if you could, please connect with me the lack of movement on the decision to maintain the current pace and quantities of bond purchases with the fact that the SEPs are showing three years with inflation not reaching 2 percent.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: Some might argue that you need to do more to start fixing those expectations, and to let this drift and say “We’re going to miss our target for another three years” doesn’t show a very firm commitment to the new framework.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: So, in terms of the vaccine, yes, you know, we do estimates of, of when the United States would reach herd immunity, and they’re, they’re going to be similar to what other people think.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, it depends on your assumptions, such as how many people will actually take the vaccine and how fast will the rollout be.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So it’s assumption based on assumption based on assumption.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, you know, sometime—it’s possible sometime in the middle or second half of next year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I’m not going to try to be precise, because it’s just another estimate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, our people are very good, but they’re looking at, at the same data as other people are.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And so, you know, all the estimates are—it depends on what your assumptions are.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But under a normal set of assumptions, it could happen as, as soon as the middle of next year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In terms of the, you know, inflation, a couple things—your second question.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, we’re—I think you have to be honest with yourself about, about inflation these days.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There are—there are significant disinflationary pressures around the world, and there have been for a while, and they persist today.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s, is not going to be easy to have inflation move up.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And it isn’t going to be just a question—it’s going to take some time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It took a long time to get inflation back to 2 percent in the last crisis.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, we’re, we’re honest with ourselves and with you in the SEP that even with the very high level of accommodation that we’re providing both through low rates and very high levels of asset purchases, it will take some time, because that’s what we believe the underlying inflation dynamics are in our economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that’s sort of why we’re—one reason why we’re concerned about inflation is that we see that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, and that’s why we have adopted the flexible average inflation-targeting framework.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s why we’re aiming for an overshoot.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But we’re, we’re honest with ourselves and with the public that it will take some time to get there.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In terms of, you know, would, would it really speed it up a lot to, to move asset purchases, you know, I don’t think that would really be—I think it’s going to take a long time however you do it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, we’ve been having very long expansions since—in, in the last several decades because inflation has not—really, the old model was, inflation would come along and the Fed would tighten, and we’d have a recession.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Now inflation has been low, and we haven’t had that dynamic.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And the result has been three of the four longest expansions in, in modern history, in recorded history.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, you know, we’re, we’re thinking that this could be another long expansion, and that we’ll keep our—what we’re saying is, we’re going to keep policy highly accommodative until the expansion is well down the tracks.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we’re not going to preemptively raise rates until we see inflation actually reaching 2 percent and being on track to exceed 2 percent.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s a very strong commitment, and we think that’s the right place to be.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Chris Rugaber.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: I’m sorry, Mr.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Chair.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: I’m just going to add, markets have actually found this fairly credible.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: If you look at what—at inflation compensation and at the survey measures of, of when the Fed will lift off, everything has moved.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There have been significant movements since we announced the framework in the direction that is consistent with the—with the framework being credible to market participants.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I, I don’t think it’s something that—I, I mean, I’m actually pleased by, by the reception it’s gotten in markets.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And markets have moved in ways that suggest it is credible.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Chris.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, thank you.
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER.

Sentences: Yesterday, I guess, the Fed said that it is joining the international financial greening group.
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER.

Sentences: And I just wanted to see if you could expand on how the Fed is thinking about climate change and how it might affect Fed policy going forward.
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER.

Sentences: Specifically, I think Janet Yellen drew a distinction between considering climate change when it comes to financial regulation.
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER.

Sentences: But how do you see that also potentially affecting monetary policy?
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER.

Sentences: Obviously, there have been criticisms of the Fed for buying bonds of oil and gas companies.
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER.

Sentences: But leaving that specific case aside, I mean, are there—is there any way that climate change considerations could affect monetary policy going forward?
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER.

Sentences: So the—you’re, you’re talking about the—sorry, the Network [of Central Banks and Supervisors] for Greening the Financial System, which we joined this week.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I’ll just—I’ll just say a couple things about that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, first, I’ll just start by saying that we’re going to move carefully and thoughtfully on developing an understanding of how climate change affects our work, including the areas you mentioned.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re going to do so with a great deal of engagement with all of our external constituencies, including the public and their elected representatives who are charged with our oversight.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’ll do it with great transparency.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Remember that we are a nonpolitical agency whose goals and authorities to achieve those goals are set by Congress.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We have great responsibilities and strong authorities that we’ll use vigorously.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re not the forum where all the great issues of the day are to be hashed out, debated, and addressed unless and only to the extent that those issues are directly relevant to our statutory goals and are addressable through our legal authorities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And because we have a narrow remit, and because we stick to it, Congress has given us a precious grant of independence from direct political control.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So society’s broad response to climate change is for others to decide—in particular, elected leaders.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But—so let me—let me get to your question.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: What does all that mean for an issue like climate change?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And why did we join the NGFS?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So Congress hasn’t explicitly assigned us or other financial regulators a role, and we’re not among the agencies who contribute to the National Climate Assessment—Climate Assessment, for example.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But climate change is nonetheless relevant to our existing mandates under the law.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And let me tell you why.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: One of our jobs is to regulate and supervise banks and to look after the stability of the financial system.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s a responsibility we share with other agencies.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The public will expect that we will—we will do that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we’ll, we’ll expect that, that those important institutions will be resilient against the many resists—risks that they fake—face:  credit risk, market risk, cyber risk.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Climate change is an emerging risk to financial institutions, the financial system, and the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we are, as so many others are, in the very early stages of understanding what that means, what needs to be done about it, and by whom.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s why 83 central banks have joined together to share research and identify best practices in this important emerging area.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’ve been attending NGFS meetings as an observer for more than a year, taking part in the work.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We had discussed that it was probably time to join as a member.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I’ll just say that the financial system is really a global one.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s important that we work and discuss best practices with peer agencies around the world, especially in a field where we’re just beginning to develop our, our understanding.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You asked about monetary policy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, I—I’ll say this.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We, we have historically shied away strongly from taking a role in credit allocation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In fact, our agreement with Treasury during the financial crisis from back in 2009 or ’10 says that we will avoid credit allocation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s something we’ve carefully avoided.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I, I would be very reluctant to see us move in that direction, picking one area as creditworthy and another not.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So you asked about monetary policy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, it’s, it’s—for now, I would say the real—the real concern is—the real place to focus, for me, is supervision of financial institutions and then financial stability concerns.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You can see a connection there.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Monetary policy, maximum employment, stable prices—it’s less obvious to me.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I can—I can, you know—I can make the argument, but it’s less obvious to me that those should be first-order things that we would look at in connection with climate change.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But I think there’s—I think there’s work to be done to understand the connection between climate change and the strength and resilience of financial markets and financial institutions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I think that work is in its early days.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, again, we’ll be careful.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’ll be thorough and transparent and, and engage with the public on all that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: CHRISTOPHER RUGABER.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Rachel Siegel.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, Chair Powell.
Speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL.

Sentences: Thanks very much for taking my question.
Speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL.

Sentences: And thank you, Michelle.
Speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL.

Sentences: I wanted to ask specifically about state and local aid.
Speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL.

Sentences: Just as one example, the governor of Illinois announced roughly $700 million in early anticipated budget cuts to close the budget deficit, and the latest bipartisan stimulus proposal that’s being debated this week seems to be leaving out state and local aid at this point.
Speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL.

Sentences: And I’m just curious if you can give some detail about the damage that these budget deficits or the lack of aid specifically to state and local governments will have on the recovery and, specifically, with the municipal lending facility set to expire, what more the Fed might be able to do to fill that specific hole.
Speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL.

Sentences: Thanks very much.
Speaker: RACHEL SIEGEL.

Sentences: Okay.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So the state and local governments, they provide important critical services:  safety, fire, police, health, all kinds of things like that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They’re, they’re really involved in people’s lives, state and local governments are, to, to a large extent.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The decision whether to, to provide more fiscal support to them is entirely in the hands of Congress.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, they’re in the middle of these discussions, and, and those, those are issues for them to decide.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I would say that the picture is mixed.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: What’s happened is, if you’re a state that has a significant exposure to tourism or to extracting energy from the ground—oil from the ground, or gas—you are probably, at least in those industries, feeling a significant loss of revenue.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: A number of other states have been surprised on the upside, where—and that’s because goods sales, for example—property taxes are—don’t move much year to year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, the kind of sales taxes on goods—goods sales have been very high.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Income has been more or less replaced by, by the CARES Act—fully replaced, more than, in many cases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So the concerns that we had at the very beginning of really serious, deep shortfalls and massive budget cuts on the part of state and local governments have not yet—have not yet occurred.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: What we’re seeing is, is that it’s different state to state.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And some states are having significant difficulties, others not so much.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The real concern, though, that still emerges is, state and local governments are very large employers, and—one of the largest.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And so far, since the pandemic began, employment has dropped by 1.3 million in—of state and local government.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So it’s, it’s a very large number of people to be—to be out of work from just that one source.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s actually significantly more than lost their jobs during the Global Financial Crisis.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that is—that is a significant—a significant part of that group is, is in education.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So when the schools reopen, a significant part of that 1.3 million would go back to work.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Nonetheless, it’s a concern.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re, we’re watching carefully to understand why that—why that many people have been let go and what are—really are the sources.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we’re monitoring it carefully, and it’s a mixed picture.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I, I just have to leave the question of what to do with fiscal policy on this to Congress.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: James Politi.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you, Michelle.
Speaker: JAMES POLITI.

Sentences: And thank you, Chair Powell.
Speaker: JAMES POLITI.

Sentences: You and the Fed have consistently said that the Fed is ready to provide the economy with more monetary support if needed and really stressed to policymakers generally that the dangers of not doing enough outweigh the risks of doing too much in a situation where there’s so much suffering in the economy.
Speaker: JAMES POLITI.

Sentences: The guidance today sort of cements asset purchases for a longer period of time but is not a big new easing step.
Speaker: JAMES POLITI.

Sentences: Why was now, with the short-term outlook deteriorating due to the new coronavirus surges, not the moment for a big new easing step?
Speaker: JAMES POLITI.

Sentences: And is it because of the medium-term outlook improving?
Speaker: JAMES POLITI.

Sentences: Or is it because the Fed just doesn’t have the capacity to sort of build that bridge over the next four to five months for the—for the people who are struggling?
Speaker: JAMES POLITI.

Sentences: Right.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I, I could go back, James, to what I said earlier, which is, this is—this is a very, very large asset purchase program.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s providing a tremendous amount of, of support for the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: If you look at the interest-sensitive parts of the economy, they’re performing very well.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The parts that are not performing well are not struggling from high interest rates.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They’re struggling from exposure to, to COVID, in a sense.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: These are—these are the businesses that, that are really hit hard by people’s reluctance to gather closely.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, so we, we do have the ability to—you know, to buy more bonds or to buy longer-term bonds.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, and we may—we may use it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I’m not saying we won’t—we won’t use that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It may well come to, to using that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But also, I would remind—I would also note, though, monetary policy works with “long and variable lags,” is the famous statement.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we think that the big effects from monetary policy are, you know, months and months into the future.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So this looks like a—you know, it looks like a time when what is really needed is fiscal policy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, and that’s why it is, is a very positive thing that, that we’re getting that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we, we remain open to doing—you know, to, to either increasing the size of our asset purchases, if that turns out to be appropriate, or to just moving the maturities, moving to buying longer maturities, because that had—that also increases accommodation by taking more duration risk out of the market.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But we think our current stance is appropriate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we think that our—you know, that our, our guidance on asset purchases today will also provide support to the economy over time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Again, what we’ve—what we’ve done is, we’ve laid out a path whereby we’re going to keep monetary policy highly accommodative for a long time, really until—really until we reach very close to our goals, which is not, you know, not really the way it’s been done in the past.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s, that’s providing significant support for the economy now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We don’t think the economy suffers from a lack of, of highly accommodative financial conditions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We think it’s suffering from the pandemic and people wanting to not engage in certain kinds of economic activity.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we expect that, that with the virus, that that will improve—that condition will improve.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Nonetheless, again, we will—are prepared to use our tools, and we will use them at such time and in such amounts as we—as we think would, would help.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Scott Horsley, NPR.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
Speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY.

Sentences: Some forecasters have suggested that there is a lot of pent-up demand for travel and entertainment and, and services and the like that might stop being pent up in a hurry if we do get to a point where the vaccine is widely distributed, and that the beaten-down service sector might have trouble meeting that demand in, in a hurry.
Speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY.

Sentences: How might that affect inflation, in your mind?
Speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY.

Sentences: And would that be just a transient problem or, or something that might warrant closer scrutiny?
Speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY.

Sentences: So that, that has all the markings of a transient increase in the price level.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So you can imagine that as people really want to travel again—let’s say, you know, that airfare, airfares—I’m just imagining this, right?—that they go up.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But what inflation is, is a process whereby they go up year upon year upon year upon year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And if—given the inflation dynamics that we’ve had over the last several decades, just a single, single sort of price-level increase has not resulted in ongoing price-level increases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that, that was—the problem back in the 1970s was, it was the combination of two things.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: One, when unemployment went down and resources got tight, prices started going up.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But the second problem was that that—that that increase was persistent, there was a level of persistence.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So if prices went up 6 percent this year, they’d go up 6 percent next year, because people would internalize.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I mean, really, really, that’s what happens is, people internalize that they can raise prices, and that it’s okay to pay prices that are going up at that rate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that was the inflation—those are the inflation dynamics of that era.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Those dynamics are not in place anymore.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There—the connection between low unemployment or other resource utilization and inflation is so much weaker than it was.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s still there, but it’s a—it’s a faint heartbeat compared to what it was.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And the persistence of inflation, if you—if you get a—for example, oil prices go up, and that’ll send a temporary shock through the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The persistence of that into, into inflation over time is just not there.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So they—what you describe may happen, and, of course, we would watch it very carefully.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We, we understand that we will always be learning new things from the economy about how it will behave in certain cases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But I would—I would expect, though, going in that that would be a one-time price increase rather than an increase in underlying inflation that would be persistent.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So not the kind of thing that the Fed would, would be trigger-happy to, to— CHAIR POWELL.
Speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY.

Sentences: No.
Speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY.

Sentences: —respond to?
Speaker: SCOTT HORSLEY.

Sentences: No, no.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Definitely not.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Michael Derby.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: [Inaudible]—question.
Speaker: MICHAEL DERBY.

Sentences: But what I wanted to ask was, you know, given the size of all the government borrowing and, you know, different regulatory changes in the financial sector, do you think that the Treasury market, long run, can operate smoothly without some sort of active Fed presence—you know, buying Treasury debt?
Speaker: MICHAEL DERBY.

Sentences: You know, I’m referring back to [inaudible] Randal Quarles.
Speaker: MICHAEL DERBY.

Sentences: He had some questions about it.
Speaker: MICHAEL DERBY.

Sentences: So I wanted to know where you stood on that issue.
Speaker: MICHAEL DERBY.

Sentences: Right.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So—you were breaking up a little.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I think—I think I got the sense of it, though.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Yes, I, I don’t think it’s at all a foregone conclusion that there needs to be a permanent Fed presence.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we certainly don’t—you know, that’s not something we’re planning on or intending.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Right now we’re buying assets because it’s a—you know, it’s a—it’s a time when the economy needs highly accommodative monetary policy, and we think our asset purchases are, you know, one of the main delivery mechanisms for that, the size of the balance sheet.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, there’s lots of demand for, for U.S. Treasury paper all—from all over the world.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I, I think we need to be thoughtful about the structure of the Treasury market and look at ways to make sure that the capacity is there for it to be handled by the private sector.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And there’s, there’s quite a lot of work going on on that front.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But I, I don’t presume at all that, that this is something that needs to be—where the Fed needs to be in there at all.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I, I would think that this should be handled by the private sector and can be.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Institutions need to be able to hold this paper.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And there may be—there may be a central clearing angle that would, you know, net a lot of risk.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s, that’s yet to be proven.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There are a lot of things that are being looked at right now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHAEL DERBY.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hannah Lang.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, hi.
Speaker: HANNAH LANG.

Sentences: Thanks so much for taking our questions.
Speaker: HANNAH LANG.

Sentences: So, you know, as you know, the pandemic has really disproportionately impacted small and medium-sized businesses.
Speaker: HANNAH LANG.

Sentences: And the Fed launched a few efforts this year to—through its 13(3) programs to reach out to those companies.
Speaker: HANNAH LANG.

Sentences: But, you know, considering that some of those programs are ending, is there anything else that the Fed’s actions can do to provide support to those companies?
Speaker: HANNAH LANG.

Sentences: Or is that solely Congress’s domain?
Speaker: HANNAH LANG.

Sentences: I think the main thing that those companies need is a—is a robust recovery—a strong, robust recovery.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And so we, we contribute to that through highly accommodative monetary policy, through accommodative financial conditions that are supporting economic activity.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Health authorities are contributing to that through, through, you know, management of the spread of the virus and now through vaccines and the delivery of those vaccines.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And Congress contributes, contributes to that by helping them make it through this very difficult time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, and I think my understanding is that there’s support for small businesses in, in what’s being discussed on Capitol Hill.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I would certainly think that would be something well worth looking at.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Paul La Monica.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, Chair Powell—hi, Chair Powell.
Speaker: PAUL LA MONICA.

Sentences: I was wondering if you’ve had any conversations yet with any members of the incoming Biden Administration, particularly Janet Yellen, who obviously you can share some similar experience in running the Fed.
Speaker: PAUL LA MONICA.

Sentences: So just curious to get your thoughts on how the relationship with Treasury and the new Administration might differ than the past couple of years.
Speaker: PAUL LA MONICA.

Sentences: So, you know, we’ve had a—and I’ve had sort of the typical meetings with the transition team for Treasury.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They’ve met with quite a lot of people in our agency and other agencies.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, really, it’s about learning what we do.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I, I really have only spoken to former Chair Yellen to congratulate her on being nominated and just to say that I look forward to working with her.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, I did work very closely with her for five years before she left and have stayed in touch, you know.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I did that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But I have not discussed, you know, policy with her.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I, I’m not going to do that until she’s confirmed.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Great, thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Jeff Cox.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Yes.
Speaker: JEFF COX.

Sentences: Chair, thank you for taking the question.
Speaker: JEFF COX.

Sentences: You’ve been asked this question before in various forms.
Speaker: JEFF COX.

Sentences: I’m going to try it a little bit differently now.
Speaker: JEFF COX.

Sentences: The equity market and the bond market seem to be telling two different stories about where, where things are heading.
Speaker: JEFF COX.

Sentences: We [inaudible] on the stock market, bond yields remain very low.
Speaker: JEFF COX.

Sentences: Does that concern you at all?
Speaker: JEFF COX.

Sentences: Are, are you getting any more concerned about asset valuations in, in light of the highly accommodative Fed policies?
Speaker: JEFF COX.

Sentences: You, you were breaking up, but I, I think I got that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I think I got it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, you know, financial stability—we, we look at a broad range of things.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We actually have a framework so that we can, you know, be—evaluate changes in financial stability over time, and so that the public can evaluate whether we’re doing a job—a good job at it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We—so what do we look at?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Asset prices is one thing that we look at.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And, you know, we published a report a few weeks ago on that—maybe it was month or so ago.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Anyway.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I think you’ll find a mixed bag there.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It depends—with equities, it depends on whether you’re looking at P/Es or whether you’re looking at the premium over risk-free—over the risk-free return.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: If you look at P/Es, they’re historically high, but, you know, in a world where the—where the risk-free rate is sustain—is going to be low for a sustained period, the equity premium, which is really the reward you get for taking equity risk, would be what you’d look at.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that’s not at, at incredibly low levels, which would mean that they’re not overpriced in that sense.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Admittedly, P/Es are high, but that’s—you know, that’s, that’s maybe not as relevant in a world where we think the 10-year Treasury is going to be lower than it’s been historically, from a—from a return perspective.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, we look at—we also look at borrowing—leverage of financial institutions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We spent 10 years and the banks spent 10 years building up their capital.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So far, they’ve been a source of strength through this crisis, and their capital has held up well.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We look at leverage in the nonfinancial sector—that’s households and nonfinancial corporates.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Nonfinancial corporate leverage is high.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’ve been watching that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, you know, rates are really low.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So—and so companies have been able to handle their debt loads even in weak periods, because rates are—rates are quite low.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Your interest payments are low.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Defaults and downgrades have, have declined since earlier in the year.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Households came into this very strong, and there certainly has been a hit there for people who are unemployed.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, you know, with the CARES Act, Congress replaced a lot of lost income.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, it’s very important that, that the economy gets strong again.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I mean, the, the ultimate thing to support financial stability is a strong economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The last thing is, is really funding markets.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We found that there was a lot of unstable funding for companies, particularly financial companies.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that’s, that’s down to a—to a very low level these days.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So the broad financial stability picture is, is kind of mixed, I would say.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I would say, you know, asset prices are, are a little high in that metric and in my view.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, overall, you have a mixed picture.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You, you don’t have, you know, a lot of red flags on that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So—and it’s—again, it’s something that we monitor essentially ongoing, almost daily.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, we’re, we’re monitoring these prices for that and, and have published our, our framework, and, you know, we’ll be held accountable for what we saw and what we missed.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we work very hard at it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: And for the last question we’ll go to Michael McKee.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, I have a couple of questions about the fiscal support for the economy.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentences: This year’s budget deficit is $3.1 trillion.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentences: And Republicans have argued they don’t want to spend more, because we can’t afford it.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentences: So I’m wondering if you can make the case for how much we can afford.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentences: At what point do deficits and the debt start to have an impact on the economy or on interest rates?
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentences: And how would we know when we get there?
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentences: So people who—people who run for elected office and win, they’re the ones—their reward is they get to make those very difficult decisions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And—you know, so we’re not charged with providing fiscal advice to, to Congress.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But I, I would just say, as a general—as a general rule, it is important to be on a sustainable fiscal path.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: For my way of thinking and many others’, the time to focus on that is when the economy is strong and when unemployment is low and taxes are—you know, are, are pouring in, and there’s, there’s room to get on—get on a sustainable path, because the economy’s really doing well.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You’re still now in the—in the, you know, some part of, of an economic crisis.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And the fact that Congress is debating a fairly large bill today suggests that, that—you know, suggests that something fairly substantial is going to get done, we hope—that what’s being discussed is, you know, is, is of some size.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In terms of what is a sustainable level, I think, you know, it’s—the question is—we’ve always looked at debt to GDP, and we’re very high by that measure.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: By some other measures, we’re actually not that high.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In particular, you can look at the real interest rate payments, the amount of, what does it cost?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And from that standpoint, if you—if you sort of take real interest costs of the federal deficit and divide that by GDP, we’re actually—you know, we’re actually on a more sustainable fiscal path if you look at it through those eyes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Again, these are—these are issues for Congress.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But, you know, I’ll just say in the near term, I think fiscal—the case for, for fiscal is, is strong.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I’m certainly hoping—I think it will be very good for the economy if, if we did get something soon.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Well, the argument for continuing to spend is that low interest rates make it affordable.
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentences: Do you worry you get in a situation where you would have congressional interference in monetary policymaking or at least feel significant political pressure to keep rates low because the country can’t afford to pay a significant interest bill?
Speaker: MICHAEL MCKEE.

Sentences: Yeah, I mean, that’s—I think we’re a very, very long way from that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, the, the Congress has given the Fed independence on the condition that we stick to our knitting.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We try very hard to do that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I, I think that’s, that’s what people call fiscal dominance.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I, I think we’re just a very, very long way from that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I think, you know, if we—if we do our jobs well and support the economy and achieve maximum employment and stable prices, keep the financial system stable, I don’t think that that is something that will—that I would worry about, certainly not in the near term.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you very much.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Good afternoon.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.
